In the Trump administration, I was a senior advisor to the secretary. I helped create the Mission Act

You can get actual numbers from the budget. So I have the advantage of knowing where to look

And that is the fact that there's 19.7 million last year delayed or canceled appointment

you know, as a retired Air Force officer, I use camp penalties here in the air ocean.
Right.
And at the height of the pandemic, I needed to get dermatology. And while the VA was telling

we'll find you a different dermatologist is that is open. The community could never shut down

that I saw on my face as the potentially cancer. It's that fortunately it was not.
But I was able to see a community dermatologist two and a half weeks from the data request.
Wow.
And I had my authorization that day. And the concern at the DoD, Camp Pendleton

Unbelievable.
To get an appointment in the community and they canceled or delayed 19.7 million appointments.
That's dangerous, taking everything else away because we know from studies that the health

Yeah.
Dude, that is the normal common sense. And that's what we put in the regulation,

They do a trick called a patient indicated date, clinically indicated date. So rather than

Nope.

And so we don't know how big that number is because that's getting a little bit old from

You don't know how bad it is. And so I have some other startling numbers that I've just

It's an atrocity. So I looked at everyone understood during COVID, whether it was right or not,
there was a decrease, but we're post-COVID now. It's fully open.
Kneecare is fully open. And so I took a look at the number of veterans who were using the VA

And so, despite what you might hear, less veterans are actually enrolled in using the VA today than

patients. Because they have to put that in their budget. Now, remember, VA is asking for record
budgets, but they have less appointments happening than they had in 2019 than they have less veterans.
In terms of the amount of roles in the VA system, you actually have 47,000 less veterans
in 2020 than 2019. In terms of unique patients, the actual number of patients that actually use

appointments, when you take the appointments that are done at the facility plus the appointments in
the community care, you had averaging this time in 2019 7.9 million appointments per month.
Wow. In 2021, based on the numbers the secretary just gave out, you're down to 5.9 million appointments.
So, you're 2 million appointments month left when you take into account. Now, you're 5% more
appointments in the facilities, but you have an 85% drop in the number of appointments in the
community. And that's just another indicator showing that they aren't letting veterans
go into the community. The number is staggering. 2.7 million appointments on average per month
in 2019 in the community. Right now, according to the secretary of testimony last week,
we are down to 416,000 appointments in the community.
Wow. So, it's described for our listeners what's happening, what's the dynamic. So,
someone tries to get permission from the VA to go to the community and they can't.
Is that what's happening? Or they've just gotten so frustrated they throw in their hands up and say,

Both. This is what we're experiencing.
And so, one trick the VA is doing to try to keep wait times down is there's a standard of 28 days
to special care. So, we have heard time to time to time again from veterans of VA scheduling
the night for day 27. So, they meet the wait time. So, they keep me at day 26. They call me up and

Wow. So, if you're doing wait times correctly, if the VA cancels you, you're still, your wait

letter without the signatures. Then we got the signatures explaining about how bad things were

I have talked directly with helping one female veteran who had all of her community care canceled,
trying to get back. I talked to a frontline primary care clinician, and she directly told me this was,
this was two months ago. She directly told me, he said, look, you need it in the community.
I'm going to put you in this community, but you're probably not going to get it. And so
the veteran said to her, well, why not? He said, well, I agree that you need it. He said, but
I don't have any authority anymore on this. The chief of staff has the authority, and this is
what she said, which was really startling. She said, in the prior administration, no problem
to get your community care. But in this administration, we have been told by this administration,
keep them at the facility, if at all possible, don't let them in the community. She was telling

With the law and the regulation, if they cannot get you an appointment for mental health time
of care within 20 days from your data request, you have the automatic right going to the community

They can always do better. It was probably the best medical interest in there, but they cannot

What's their motive? I mean, you assume that people that go to work for the VA went to work

But if you are thwarting the options that Congress created to solve the prior wait time crisis,

I think it's some of the things that you said. This is the same culture that the current secretary

You asked a very good pertinent question, which is, why would they do this? I would tell you,

they leak information to others. But there's a level of middle and upper management,
which are career, and I've seen this, I've been in an IVA for 20 years, in the Bush
and the Trump administration. They think they know better than VSOs, veterans,
the hill, the American people. They think this is my agency. When people don't understand,
what is this administrative state or detail? What is this? This is the career bureaucrats who think

a large percentage of veterans have given the choice will not accept this kind of customer
service these kind of wait times and will go into the community. 80% of veterans already

the average veteran only uses VA for 35% of their care. They're in the community already,
and they're in the other health insurance for 65% of their care. VA is the most
expensive health care. They also see the few amount of patients they only see on average 10
patients a day when they're fully operational. Why would they do that? They do that because
they are of the money and the power and the budget. The community care money is separate

many patients will show up to the medical facility. If they lose the patients to the community because
of the poor service- They lose the dollars, right?
Then they will lose staff and funding for the medical center. It's not that year,

how many patients did you have? And that makes sense, right? How many patients do you have there
for how many dollars did you have for staff? And they don't want to lose it. Instead,
they go to Congress asking for and getting billions of dollars or $20 billion more over the last year.
They're adding 17,000 staff. And I have to just say to staff in the
LSE, I said, why would you give an organization that has less customers, less patients,
and are doing less business to your appointments in the last two years? Why would they get $20 billion

It's not being used on the bedroom.
Yep, no, clearly not. No. It's going to their own pockets in bureaucracy. That's what it is.
More staff to do what?
We gave our promise to these veterans that we would give them care for putting themselves in

Well, it's a big problem. And different problems for a number of reasons. VA was created.

Right. It was not meant to be Kaiser. And even with a Kaiser, people say, well,
transgender, Kaiser offers it. Well, Kaiser offers it if you buy it. Kaiser offers it if you pay an

plan, they don't have dental. They don't have elective surgeries. One female veteran was
laying this meeting who was upset about the transgender stuff. She said, look, you will take

But I have, I need breast reconstructive surgery from what happened to me in
combat over in Iraq and everything. But they won't give that to me.
I just don't know if it will.
So it is this upside down. The problem with this and my concern with this is that there's a normal

to do elective surgery because people feel bad about themselves and that go both ways in terms of
people who've had that kind of surgery who then regret it and then went on do it.
Then you've got to go through a proper process of going talking to your stakeholders, talking to
